>>>If you come up to me right now and tell me 40 minutes ago, I was doing something but you won't provide any proof and that's enough to get me in trouble, I don't think that's okay.">>>

Then go to court and argue your case.
You don't get to "demand" anything, sweety. You don't get to demand the footage of the camera that busted you selling drugs, either.
You go to trial and present your case...they'll present theirs. That's how it works, kid.

replies.context:
What are you talking about? Before the trial you are supposed to get access/see the evidence against you. And yes you do get to demand the evidence. All the evidence  is some thing you get to see, and before trial.
At your 1st appear in front of the judge the police are legally required to say there is proof you may have committed a crime. And if that proof is video, at the least they say it is proof you committed a crime. Every state has varied rules of evidence on video evidence. Drone footage must be properly entered as evidence.
The Discovery Phase is where all evidence is presented to the court and gets the OK to use in the hearing.
